deity.name: Lunitari
deity.title: High Goddess of Neutral Magic
entries: Long ago, this world was one of tumultuous and chaotic forces. Naught but unbridled fires, and churning, sawlike rock made up its substance. Through the ashen skies of Creation Primordial, three gods, the Estelar, came from beyond the ether, new and formless. They took the guise of three stars, and each took a name: {@deity Lunitari|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers}, {@deity Solinari|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} and {@deity Nuitari|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers}. These three danced together for what felt like ages, creating the new gods: the gods of The Founding. Looking upon this roiling realm, the new gods saw potential for great beauty, great strength, and the chance to learn their own place in creation.

During the creation of the world, Lunitari, the most powerful of the trio, gave the realm it's Primal source of magic, and with it, the Weave. Lunitari created {@deity Corellon|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} to hold dominion over the weave.

entries.name: Lunitari’s Gift
entries: According to legend, Lunitari sent an enormous meteor hurtling toward Ilúvë thousands of years ago. This celestial body buried itself miles beneath the surface somewhere in Nordurvilt. The pulsing core of the meteorite has never cooled in the countless centuries since. This core is said to hold a priceless gift from the High Goddess, though the precise nature of this gift has not been agreed on. Some say it is the purest platynar in the multiverse, while others say the gift is a deep philosophical truth.
It is said that the only way to reach Lunitari's Gift is a narrow natural bridge deep within the Underdark. Monsters from across the planes said to guard it.

deity.title: High God of Good Magic

Both Solinari and Nuitari rain down new chunks of platinum and brimstone every 1,000 years. This event is known as "Dawnfire". Solinari was also responsible for creating both {@deity Melora|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} and {@deity Erathis|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers}.

deity.name: Avandra
deity.title: Goddess of Change and Luck
deity.province: Adventure, Change, Freedom, Luck and Travel

entries: Also known as "She Who Makes the Path", Avandra champions freedom, travel, trade, and adventure across the lands. Her will heralds open frontiers, and her call beckons her followers to discover that which awaits them beyond the known. There are few urban temples dedicated to the Change Bringer, but her shrines are often found along well-traveled roads and off the beaten path. Her worship is common among merchants, free spirits, and adventurers, and tavern cheers celebrate her as a bringer of luck and fortune.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Change Bringer is often depicted as a young woman of dark complexion and long, light brown hair that cascades to form the road left behind her. Most art shows her in constant motion, ever leading into the unknown.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Avandra's holy day, called New Dawn, takes place on the first day of the first month, when the old year gives way to the new. In the Bramble Downs, people celebrate by having a feast on the shore near Port Delthuntle at dusk to watch the sunset. They feast and discuss their hopes for the new year until the sun rises.

items: Luck favors the bold. Your fate is your own to grasp, and to do so is to have the Change Bringer behind you.
Change is inevitable. The righteous can ensure that such change is for the better.
Rise against tyranny. Fight for the freedom of yourself and others when you can, and inspire others to fight when you cannot.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Avandra when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Supporting those who would reform or overturn institutions
Overthrowing a tyrant who threatens freedom
Taking bold action when others are indecisive
Creating or maintaining a roadside shrine to Avandra

entries: Your piety score to Avandra decreases if you diminish Avandra's influence in the world, contradict her ideal of gradual change, or attempt to impose artificial order through acts such as these:

items: Upholding an unjust or tyrannical institution
Abusing the goodwill of another
Hesitating in a moment of crisis

entries.name: Avandra's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Avandra trait}

As a devotee of Avandra, you have proven yourself a worthy representative of the Goddess of luck. You can cast {@spell longstrider} with this trait. You can cast the spell in this way a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Avandra's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Avandra trait}

You can cast {@spell fortune's favor|EGW} at third level with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Avandra's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Avandra trait}
Avandra's blessing makes it harder to keep you in place; you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition paralyzed} or {@condition restrained}.

entries.name: Champion of the Crossroads
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Avandra trait}
You can increase your Dexterity or Wisdom score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Ioun
deity.title: Goddess of Knowledge
deity.province: Knowledge, Prophecy, Psionics, Skill and Study
deity.symbol: Crook shaped like a stylized eye

entries: Revered by seers, sages, and teachers of all walks of life, Ioun guided the growth of civilization throughout the Age of Magicka like sunlight guides the branches of a tree. Grievously wounded by Tharizdun during the Dawn War, her followers are now hunted by agents of her ancient foes as she recovers. Her devout now worship in private, spreading knowledge, philosophy, and lore anonymously through traceless channels.

entries.name: Ioun's Influence
entries: Ioun is depicted among the infinite library that fills the mythical, hidden realm of the Endless Athenaeum, her celestial servants cataloging all known things as she inspires those who pray for her insight and guidance.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Common representations show the Knowing Mentor as a graying, mature woman with a welcoming, matronly smile, swathed in billowing robes and scarves that fan into books and scrolls. Some colloquially refer to Ioun as the Knowing Mistress, revering her as a headmistress of knowledge among the gods.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Ioun has no public holy day, for her public worship was shattered after the disappearance of The Chroniclers, and she has since fallen into half-remembered myth. Only in the monasteries of the Hand of Eon's Minute and The Red Tower has the Knowing Mentor's faith been resurrected—though her worship by the intellectuals of these places bears little resemblance to that of the knowledge-seekers of old.

items: Seek the perfection of your mind by bringing reason, perception, and emotion into balance with one another.
Accumulate, preserve, and distribute knowledge in all forms. Pursue education, build libraries, and seek out lost and ancient lore.
Be watchful at all times for the followers of Vecna, who seek to control knowledge and keep secrets. Oppose their schemes, unmask their secrets, and blind them with the light of truth and reason.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Ioun when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Revealing a critical truth or dangerous secret
Discovering or documenting an unknown people or a poorly understood creature
Solving a challenging riddle or puzzle
Helping a community successfully plan for or adapt to a threat

entries: Your piety score to Ioun decreases if you diminish her influence in the world through acts such as these:

items: Selfishly refusing to share information
Hiding or destroying research or other sources of knowledge
Willingly subverting or impeding a wise course of action
Failing to plan appropriately for a challenge

entries.name: Ioun's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Ioun trait}

As a devotee of Ioun, you are a font of knowledge on all things. You can cast the {@spell identify} spell without needing to provide material components with this trait a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Ioun's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Ioun trait}

You can cast the {@spell divination} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Ioun's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Ioun trait}
You develop a sixth sense, allowing you to intuit the future. You can't be {@condition surprised}, provided you aren't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Oracle of Ioun
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Ioun trait}
You can increase your Intelligence or Wisdom score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Bahamut
deity.title: God of Justice and Nobility
deity.province: Honor, Justice, Metallic Dragons, Nobility and Protection

entries: Called the Platinum Dragon, Bahamut is the god of justice, protection, nobility, and honor. Lawful good paladins often revere him, and metallic dragons worship him as the first of their kind. Monarchs are crowned in his name. The crest of the Platinum Dragon adorns many halls of high leadership and justice, invoking his will in all matters of justice. To follow him is to look after those who cannot look after themselves.

entries.name: Bahamut's Influence
entries: Bahamut is depicted to reside within his magnificent, glittering palace of gold, platinum, and mithril, known as the Govoldeim Palace.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Platinum Dragon is often seen emblazoned on shields and armor, both functional and decorative, in the form of a brilliant dragon head in profile. Temples and works of art depict a massive, glittering dragon with vibrant platinum scales and seemingly endless wingspan.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Bahamut's holy day is called Embertide, and is celebrated on the fifth day of Duscar. This is a day of remembrance, solemnity, and respect for those who have fallen in the defense of others.

items: Uphold the highest ideals of honor and justice.
Be constantly vigilant against evil and oppose it on all fronts.
Protect the weak, liberate the oppressed, and defend just order.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Bahamut when you expand his influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Carrying out punishment on a fugitive from justice
Overcoming great odds honorably
Defending a law abiding creature or city from attacking monsters
Building or restoring a temple to Bahamut

entries: Your piety score to Bahamut decreases if you diminish his influence in the world, contradict his ideals, or make him look ridiculous or ineffectual through acts such as these:

items: Breaking an explicit promise or oath
Violating any just law
Putting others at risk through your own cowardice
Besting an honorable foe through deceit

entries.name: Bahamut's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Bahamut trait}

As a devotee of Bahamut, you have earned his favor through victories won in his name. You can cast the {@spell compelled duel} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Bahamut's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Bahamut trait}

You can cast the {@spell crusader's mantle} spell with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell. In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Bahamut's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Bahamut trait}

As a bonus action, you can call on Bahamut's blessing, gaining the following benefit for 1 minute or until you are {@condition incapacitated}: creatures within 30 feet of you can't gain advantage on attack rolls against you. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Servitor of the Seven Wyrms
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Bahamut trait}
You can increase your Strength or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Erathis
deity.title: Goddess of Civilization and Invention
deity.symbol: Upper half of a clockwork gear

entries: The inspiration behind many great inventions, the creation of vast cities, and law and order within society, Erathis claims dominion over civilization. Judges and rulers pay respect at her temples, which are central structures in many cities across Ilúvë. Peace and order through structure and law guides the will of her devout followers. The Law Bearer has a tempestuous romance with {@deity Melora|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} the Wild Mother, a furious love that is tempered only when civilization and nature are in balance.

entries.name: Erathis' Influence
entries: Erathis is depicted within the glorious divine metropolis of Hestavar, the Bright City. This glowing oasis is said to be barely visible, almost like a distant reflection, in the astral sea, as the Law Bearer watches over the denizens bathed in the endless daytime that illuminates the busy streets.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Erathis is shown in most texts and statues as a hooded, armored woman sitting atop a throne of pillars. Her face is generally obscured or depicted without expression, giving her presence an impartial yet imposing nature.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: The Law Bearer's holy day is Civilization's Dawn, which is celebrated on the autumnal equinox, usually the twenty-second day of the ninth month. In the Empire, people celebrate by having feasts in honor of the laws set by the Inner Cabinet. One seat at every table is left open for the Emperor, who eats in spirit with the people he rules.

items: Work with others to achieve your goals. Community and order are always stronger than the disjointed efforts of lone individuals.
Tame the wilderness to make it fit for habitation, and defend the light of civilization against the encroaching darkness.
Seek out new ideas, new inventions, new lands to inhabit, new wilderness to conquer. Build machines, build cities, build empires.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Erathis when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Defending a city from a major threat
Upholding the laws of the land in a moment of chaos
Creating a masterwork, such as a building or invention

entries: Your piety score to Erathis decreases if you diminish her influence in the world, contradict her ideals, or let her down through acts such as these:

items: Betraying one's trust to commit acts of corruption or tyranny
Destroying a civic institution or sowing chaos within a city
Willfully breaking just laws for personal gain
Extorting others for one's own wealth or well-being

entries.name: Erathis' Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Erathis trait}

Erathis grants you insight into how creatures communicate. You can cast the {@spell comprehend languages} spell with this trait, requiring no material component, a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Erathis' Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Erathis trait}

You gain advantage on Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks while you are within a city. In addition, when you fail an Intelligence check or Intelligence saving throw, you can reroll the die, and you must use the new roll. Once you use this reroll, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Erathis' Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Erathis trait}
You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition paralyzed}.

entries.name: Justicar of Hestavar
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Erathis trait}
You can increase your Strength, Intelligence or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Pelor
deity.title: God of Time and The Sun
deity.province: The Sun, Time, Light, Summer and Agriculture
deity.symbol: Circle with six outwardly radiating points or Silver sun or full moon partially eclipsed by a smaller crescent moon

entries: Pelor rules over sun and summer, his vigil encircling the ages as the keeper of time. As lord of agriculture and harbinger of the harvest, he is worshiped by farmers and most common folk, and his priests are welcomed in many lands. Supporter of the needy and destroyer of evil, the Dawn Father is often the patron of paladins and rangers who follow a similar creed. He is also known for his defeat of the Chained Oblivion and is revered by those who hunt aberrations.

entries.name: Pelor's Influence
entries: Pelor is often depicted within the Fortress of the Sun, a shining, golden citadel that is said to bring vibrant life to the burning Sun high in Ilúvë's sky.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Tapestries of old match early texts describing Pelor as a paternal figure in silver and gold armor, his head a beacon of light and fire so bright that his face can barely be seen. Many statues in holy places use the head as a brazier, lit with each dawn and extinguished at dusk.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Pelor's holy day is called Highsummer, and takes place on the fifteenth day of the seventh month. While other parts of Ilúvë feast, the Empire uses this day as an opportunity to enlist more soldiers in its army. The military holds great feasts and hands out toy soldiers and other propaganda, encouraging people to enlist and help fight against the evil that threatens the Emperor.

items: Alleviate suffering wherever you find it.
Bring Pelor’s light into places of darkness, showing kindness, mercy, and compassion.
Be watchful against evil.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Pelor when you expand his influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Turning a wild field into fertile cropland
Offering food to the starving, hope to the broken, succor to the wounded, and mercy to the defeated
Helping those who have lost themselves to darkness find their way back to the light
Standing against the forces of darkness

entries: Your piety score to Pelor decreases if you diminish his influence in the world, contradict his ideals, or undermine his civilizing influence through acts such as these:

items: Destroying a settlement's food source, or releasing and scattering domestic animals
Starting a fire that threatens a settlement
Treating a defeated enemy with cruelty
Conducting secret business under the cover of night
Allowing darkness to encroach on civilization or threaten the innocent

entries.name: Pelor's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Pelor trait}

As a devotee of Pelor, you have proven yourself a worthy champion of the sun god. You can call on Pelor's favor and cast the {@spell bless} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Pelor's blessing manifests as a nimbus around the affected creatures, causing them to shed dim light in a 5-foot radius until the spell ends. You can cast the spell in this way a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Pelor's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Pelor trait}
You can cast the {@spell daylight} spell with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Pelor's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Pelor trait}
You grow accustomed to the blazing radiance of the sun; you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, and you have resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Lightbearer
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Pelor trait}
You can increase your Constitution or Wisdom score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: The Raven Queen
deity.title: Goddess of Death and Winter
deity.province: Death, Fate, Frost, Mortality, Twilight, and Winter

entries: The name of the goddess of death is long forgotten, but she is called the Raven Queen. She is the spinner of fate and the patron of winter. She marks the end of each mortal life, and mourners call upon her during funeral rites, in the hope that she will guard the departed from the curse of undeath. Those who study ancient lore believe that the Matron of Death was once mortal herself and is the only known mortal to have ascended to godhood. Her rise instantly obliterated the previous, now-forgotten god of death, and the other gods quickly and fearfully destroyed the secrets to the rites of ascension.

entries.name: The Raven Queen's Influence
entries: The Raven Queen tugs at the threads of fate from her stronghold of black ice within the frozen realm of Letherna.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Few existing visual depictions of the Raven Queen exist; many temples merely use the raven as a symbol of her blessing. The few illustrations of her portray a tall, pale woman wrapped in dangling black linens, with her face obscured by a white porcelain mask and her onyx-black hair straight and neverending.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: The Raven Queen's holy day is called the Night of Ascension, celebrating her apotheosis. The actual date of the her rise to divinity is unclear, but the Night of Ascension is celebrated on the thirteenth day of the tenth month.

items: Death is the natural end of life. There is no pity for those who have fallen.
The path of Fate is sacrosanct. Those who pridefully attempt to cast off their destiny must be punished.
Undeath is an atrocity. Those who would pervert the transition of the soul must be brought down.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to the Raven Queen when you honor her or the cycle of life and death through acts such as these:

items: Overseeing burial rites for those slain during a tragedy
Ensuring that the deeds and knowledge of someone who has died are preserved
Slaying undead

entries: Your piety score to the Raven Queen decreases if you diminish her influence in the world, impede her work, or disrespect the dead through acts such as these:

items: Denying a dying person their final rites
Removing wealth from a corpse or defiling a tomb
Aiding those who seek to deny fate or escape from the afterlife, or who already have

entries.name: Raven Queen's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Raven Queen trait}

Your life is intertwined with the fate of the dead. You can cast the {@spell gentle repose} spell with this trait, requiring no material components, a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Raven Queen's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Raven Queen trait}

You can cast the {@spell speak with dead} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Raven Queen's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Raven Queen trait}

You can cast the {@spell false life} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. When you do so, you gain an additional 25 temporary hit points. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Covenant of Letherna
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Raven Queen trait}
You can increase your Constitution or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Sarenrae
deity.title: Goddess of Redemption and Healing
deity.province: Atonement, Compassion, Fire, Glory, Healing, Heroism, Peace, Redemption and Ressurection

entries: Goddess of atonement and compassion, Sarenrae spreads the message of understanding and optimism in even the darkest of places. She believes that the corrupt can be redeemed, a mindset that led to a betrayal by the Lord of the Nine Hells, who decimated her followers during the Dawn War. This misplaced trust caused many priests to strike her name from historical records, leaving her title and faith scattered to obscurity for much of the recent age. Only recently has her faith been rediscovered and her temples returned to prominence. The Everlight's followers are often rural healers and community philosophers, offering a voice of reason and empathy in angry and cynical times.

entries.name: Sarenrae's Influence
entries: Sarenrae guides her people from within her temple beside the crystal beaches of the Island of Renewal, a hidden sanctuary of flame said to be visible from the blessed fields of Thelanis as a strange mirage.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Those who bring the Everlight's words back to the light unearth her image from ruined temples, or create new art to inspire others with her message. Sarenrae is represented as a beautiful, strong woman with dark skin and light hair, rising betwixt a set of angelic ivory wings.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: The Everlight's holy day is referred to as Burning Blades. Burning Blades focuses on the sun and the goddess' powers of healing. It gets its name from the dance of the burning blades, in which worshipers dip ceremonial weapons in pitch or another flammable substance, and dance with the burning brands in hand. Legends recount that if one of Sarenrae's faithful is in mortal danger on this festival day, his or her weapon will burn with a holy fire. This has proven to actually be true so many times throughout history, that those with bad intentions generally avoid the Dawnflower's faithful on this day.

items: Lead with mercy, patience, and compassion. Inspire others to unite in fellowship.
Aid those who are without guidance. Heal those who are without hope.
Those who are beyond redemption, who revel in slaughter and remorseless evil, must be dispatched with swift justice.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Sarenrae when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Showing mercy to a yielding foe
Showing compassion, understanding and even giving gifts to those less fortunate
Aiding in the building or rebuilding of any prime deity's temple, especially of Sarenrae herself

entries: Your piety score to Sarenrae decreases if you diminish her influence in the world, contradict her ideals, or undermine her merciful influence through acts such as these:

items: Showing apathy towards others, especially towards followers of Sarenrae
Lessen understanding and undermining morality regarding others
Unsuccessfully bringing ne'erdowells and remorseless creatures to justice

entries.name: Sarenrae's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Sarenrae trait}

You are a beacon of compassion fighting against the evils of the world. You can cast the {@spell cure wounds} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Sarenrae's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Sarenrae trait}

You can cast the {@spell speak with dead} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Sarenrae's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Sarenrae trait}

You can cast the {@spell fire shield} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Vigilant of The Dawn
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Sarenrae trait}
You can increase your Wisdom or Constitution score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: The Red Knight
deity.title: Goddess of Strategy
deity.province: Planning and Strategy
deity.symbol: Red knight lanceboard piece with stars for eyes

entries: The Red Knight is the goddess of planning and strategy. Those who favor her call themselves the Red Fellowship. They believe wars are won by the best planning, strategy, and tactics. The worship of the Red Knight is filled with doctrine about strategy, such as: "Every war is a series of battles. Losing one doesn't mean losing the war." "In war, plan for peace. In peace, plan for war." "Seek allies among your enemy's enemies."

Worship of The Red Knight arose among a hero-venerating monastic order of Bahamut in somewhere shortly after the Crown Wars; a War waged by multiple Elven kingdoms resulting in the destruction of at least 3 of them. The Red Knight has since grown in popularity because of what her followers call the Great Stratagem: for decades, her priests have been traveling to places of warfare to educate generals and kings in the arts of strategy and battlefield tactics. Many of the leaders they approached turned them away at first, but it soon became apparent that those who accepted the counsel of the Crimson General's followers gained a distinct benefit. Grateful victors built temples to the Lady of Strategy, and gradually her faith spread.

Today, followers of the Red Knight can be found in nearly any land that has seen warfare in the past century. Worshipers of the Red Knight are rare in the general population, but those who revere her can frequently be found among high-ranking commanders of armies, instructors in colleges of war, quartermasters, and the authors of tomes of strategy. Each temple to the Red Knight includes an altar dedicated to Bahamut, and so such a place is likely to be frequented by mercenaries and soldiers. A temple is surrounded by a vast pavilion and courtyard, which can be rented by companies of soldiers and mercenaries for practice and training. Her priests believe that drilling one's troops in a temple courtyard is a form of propitiation that the Red Knight looks upon with special favor.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Red Knight is largely undepicted, due to her not directly interfering with many occurences on the material plane. When she is depicted, however, she is usually seen as a tall, long-haired blonde maiden wearing full plate armor and sporting a billowing red cloak. She also wields a large longsword, named "Checkmate".

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: The Red Knight's holy day is known as The Queen's Gambit, which is celebrated on the 1st of the 4th month. During this day-long extravaganza, the Red Fellowship gets to unwind by feasting and gaming. Day-long tournaments of chess (also known as lanceboard, hence the Red Knight's second title, "Grandmaster of the Lanceboard") are held, with the tournament victors receiving recognition, titles of merit, promotions, and occasionally a gift from the temple armory.

items: War is won by those with the best planning, strategy, and tactics, regardless of the apparent odds. Any fool can snatch defeat from the jaws of victory with fortune's aid. Only a master strategist can ensure lasting victory.
In times of war prepare for peace; in times of peace prepare for war.

Seek out your opponent's weaknesses and recognize your own; avoid an opponent’s strengths and play to your own. Only by focusing one's own strengths on the opponent's vulnerabilities can triumph be ensured.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to The Red Knight when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Respecting and aiding war instructors and strategists
Aiding those who are in dire need of sound planning and strategies
Winning wars through thorough and careful planning

entries: Your piety score to The Red Knight decreases if you diminish her influence in the world, contradict her ideals, or undermine her strategical influence through acts such as these:

items: Wilfully disregarding authority or acting against just and righteous law
Being rashful, unwilling or uncooperative towards strategists or lawgivers
Making sloppy, rushed, unplanned decisions on a whim

entries.name: The Red Knight's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Red Knight trait}

Your voice carries meaning, and depth. You become the voice of reason. This is reflected by the gift The Red Knight has bestowed upon you. You can cast the {@spell heroism} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: The Red Knight's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Red Knight trait}

Your ability to relay carefully planned-out information broadens. You can cast the {@spell sending} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: The Red Knight's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Red Knight trait}

You can cast the {@spell glibness} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Eminent Strategist
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Red Knight trait}
You can increase your Intelligence or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Kord
deity.title: God of Storms
deity.province: Athletics, Bravery, Competition, Courage, Storms and Strength
deity.symbol: Four bolts of lightning radiating from the center of a shield

entries: Where thunder booms and conflict rises, prayers to the Storm Lord are shouted into the maelstrom. Reveling in all tests of strength, Kord blesses those who prove themselves on the battlefield. Worshiped by athletes and warriors all across Ilúvë, he exalts those whose force of spirit and desire for victory call his attention. He brings tumultuous storms over land and sea, and those who wish for clearer skies offer their praises and prayers to appease him.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Within his temples, Kord is shown as a quintessential warrior, often nude with a beard and short, curled hair. As the epitome of muscle and strength, most art depicts the Storm Lord in a stance of dominance, and perhaps wrestling a terrible beast.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Kord's holy day is the Day of Challenging, which is celebrated on the seventh day of the second month. The Day of Challenging is one of the most raucous holidays in Daggerford, and thousands of spectators attend the annual Godsbrawl held in the Temple of Kord to root for their favored deity's champion, particularly the chosen champions of the Storm Lord and the All-Hammer.

items: Bravery above all. There is no glory in cowardice.
Strength is the path to greatness, but greatness is the responsible use of strength.
The glory of the Storm Lord lives through your own glory on the battlefield.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Kord when you expand the god's influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Achieving a great victory
Smiting your foes in Kord's name
Defeating a skilled foe in single combat
Winning in a display of great strength or skill, or accoplishing a great feat of might

entries: Your piety score to Kord decreases if you diminish Kord's influence in the world, contradict his ideals, or make him look weak and cowardly through acts such as these:

items: Showing cowardice in battle
Giving in to bloodlust and wanton destruction
Harming innocents or noncombatants

entries.name: Kord's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Kord trait}

As a devotee of Kord, you have proven your wisdom and your allegiance to the Storm Lord. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can deal an extra {@dice 1d6} lightning damage to the target. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your Strength or Constitution modifier, your choice (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Kord's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Kord trait}
When you fail a Strength or a Constitution saving throw, you can reroll the die, and you must use the new roll. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Kord's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Kord trait}
The energy of the storm fills your being, granting you advantage on initiative rolls.

entries.name: Warrior of Ysgard
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Kord trait}
You can increase your Strength or Constitution score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Hextor
deity.title: God of War and Conquest
deity.province: Conflict, Conquest, Discord, Massacres and War
deity.symbol: Six arrows facing downward in a fan

entries: Blood-drenched armies of brutal warriors oft crush their foes in the name of Hextor, the evil patron of war and conquest. To serve his will is to accept the call to conflict, seeking lesser people to break and subjugate. Warmongering nations and goblinoid tribes worship the Scourger as they strike out at the world to bend it beneath them. Hextor twists all living things to his iron will, forcing even nature itself to bow to his whims.

entries.name: Hextor's Influence
entries: Hextor plots his conquest from within the bastion of Banehold.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Hextor is often depicted as a hideous, gray skinned, six-armed humanoid bearing two large tusks jutting from its lower jaw wearing armor clad with skulls. He wields a weapon in each hand: a spiked flail, a battle axe, a battle pick, a longsword, a mace, and a falchion.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: The Scourger's greatest enemy is Melora, who defeated him at Icegale Ridge during the Dawn War. The Scourger grew his armies by corrupting noble creatures into monsters and destroying the wilds to fuel his terrible engines of conflict, and the two deities clashed many times during the war before his defeat at Helm's Hand.

items: Never allow your fear to gain mastery over you, but drive it into the hearts of your foes.
Punish insubordination and disorder.
Hone your combat skills to perfection, whether you are a mighty general or a lone mercenary.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Hextor when you expand his influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Crushing those who would resist your rule
Destroying harbingers of chaos, such as bandits, thieves, and other lawbreakers
Slaying servants of Gruumsh

entries: Your piety score to Hextor decreases if you diminish Hextor's influence in the world, contradict his ideals, or make him look weak or ineffectual through acts such as these:

items: Allowing your subordinates to question you
Publicly displaying weakness, mercy, or compassion
Rejecting a duel or a challenge out of fear

entries.name: Hextor's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Hextor trait}

As a devotee of Hextor, you have shown yourself to be a ruthless soldier. You can call on Hextor's favor and cast the {@spell wrathful smite} spell with this trait. Hextor's blessing manifest as a blood-red glow around your weapon, causing it to shed dim light in a 5-foot radius until the spell ends. You can cast the spell in this way a number of times equal to your Strength modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Strength is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Hextor's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Hextor trait}
You can cast the {@spell fear} spell with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Strength is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Hextor's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Hextor trait}
Countless battles and and rigorous training have given you focus. You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Blood Conqueror
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Hextor trait}
You can increase your Strength or Constitution score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Gruumsh
deity.title: God of Destruction
deity.province: Carnage, Destruction, Pillaging, Savageness, Slaughter, Warmongering

entries: Gruumsh commands hordes of barbaric marauders to destroy, pillage, and slaughter for the sheer joy of it. Orderless and without honor, the creeds of the evil hordemaster urge savage creatures to devour the world around them, giving in to the chaotic and selfish nature of the predator. A number of violent clans of humanoids and beasts across Nordurvilt pay homage to Gruumsh, asking him to bless their hunts and gift them with spoils worth ruining.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Primitive clay representations in barbaric communities of his followers show the Ruiner as a hulking, bulbous behemoth of an orc. His missing eye has shifted, and the prominent eye is now centered in his face, like a nightmarish cyclops.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: Corellon shot out Gruumsh's right eye during the Dawn War, and the god of slaughter longs for the day he can return the favor twofold. Those who serve the Ruiner are sometimes hypnotized by his hateful rage from across the Divine Gate and fall into a strange bloodlust, longing to slaughter elves and those who worship magic at the altar of the Archheart.

items: Ruin. Conquer. Kill.
The weak exist to be crushed by the strong. Be the strong.
There are no emotions but fury and joy. The rest are weakness.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Gruumsh when you expand his influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Killing elves and goblinoids
Taking vengeance against a powerful foe
Burning a city or other settlement to the ground
Desecrating a temple to Hextor, Corellon, or Lolth as an offering to Gruumsh

entries: Your piety score to Gruumsh decreases if you diminish Gruumsh's influence in the world, contradict his ideals, or make him look weak or ineffectual through acts such as these:

items: Failing to carry out a sworn vendetta
Allowing another person to give you orders
Fleeing from combat
Offering mercy to your foes

entries.name: Gruumsh's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Gruumsh trait}

As a devotee of Gruumsh, you have shown yourself to be a savage killer. You can cast the {@spell hunter's mark} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Gruumsh's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Gruumsh trait}

You can cast the {@spell blinding smite} spell with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Gruumsh's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Gruumsh trait}

The scent of fresh blood gives you the vigor needed to keep fighting—and keep killing. When a creature dies within 10 feet of you, you can use your reaction to gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your level.

entries.name: Prime Subjugator
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Gruumsh trait}
You can increase your Strength or Dexterity score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Moradin
deity.title: God of Creation
deity.province: Creation, Crafting, Designing, Earth, Protection, Pride and Smithing

entries: Moradin is worshiped by smiths, artisans, and miners alike, granting inspiration in exchange for respect and prayer. He shaped the mountains from the chaos of the Founding, and stands as the patron protector of home and family. The devotion to the All-Hammer is strongest in dwarven communities, and many temples to Moradin mark the center of a mighty dwarven stronghold.

entries.name: Moradin's Influence
entries: Moradin lords over the soul forges within the massive tunneled mansion of Erackinor, deep beneath the slopes of the mythical mountain of Abbathror.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Many guild halls and workshops contain images of Moradin, a faceless, stout dwarven being of immense strength, hunched over a flaming heart clasped within his massive hands.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Moradin's holy day is Deep Solace, which is celebrated on the eighteenth day of the fifth month. Especially devout followers of the All-Hammer spend the day in isolation, meditating on the meaning of family and how they may be better mothers, fathers, siblings, and children. The dwarvish citadel of Dor Gonnoth celebrates with a full day of feasting and drinking.

items: Meet adversity with stoicism and tenacity.
Demonstrate loyalty to your family, your clan, your leaders, and your people.
Strive to make a mark on the world, a lasting legacy. To make something that lasts is the highest good, whether you are a smith working at a forge or a ruler building a dynasty.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Moradin when you expand his influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Honoring an oath made by an ancestor
Remaining calm and taking control in a crisis situation
Giving something that has outlived its usefulness to someone who could use it more
Creating something wondrous in Moradin's name

entries: Your piety score to Moradin decreases if you diminish Moradin's influence in the world, work against freedom or self-expression, or allow tyranny to take hold through acts such as these:

items: Dishonoring your family or clan
Creating something shoddy or flawed
Destroying the creation of yourself or another
Panicking or fleeing in the face of adversity

entries.name: Moradin's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Moradin trait}

As a devotee of Moradin, you have drawn the notice of the forge god with your skill. You can cast the {@spell shield of faith} spell with this trait, requiring no material components, a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
In addition, you know the {@spell mending} cantrip. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Moradin's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Moradin trait}

You can cast the {@spell heat metal} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.
In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against being knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: Moradin's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Moradin trait}
While you are standing and are subject to an effect that would push you 1 foot or more, you can use your reaction to not be pushed.

entries.name: Forgemaster
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Moradin trait}
You can increase your Strength or Wisdom score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Melora
deity.title: Goddess of Wilderness and The Sea
deity.province: Beasts, Critters, Nature, Wilderness and The Sea

entries: The realm of Melora extends to wherever the seas shift and the land grows wild. As the keeper of the wilderness, Melora represents the wild creatures of nature, the rush of the angry rapids, and the heat-heavy stillness of the desert. Elves worship her, as do hunters, accepting her guidance to exist harmoniously within savage lands. Those seeking safe passage across dangerous waters pray to her to guide them.

Followers of the Raven Queen also show respect to the Wild Mother as the caretaker of what remains when the Matron of Death's work is done. Druids of Melora the Wild Mother and clerics of her lover, {@deity Erathis|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} the Law Bearer, work together to preserve the balance of nature and civilization. However, worship of Melora was outlawed in the Empire, causing disagreement between clerics of Erathis within The Bramble Downs, where many blame poor weather and natural disasters on the ire of their deity's partner.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Immortalized through wooden reliefs and carved idols in hidden, overgrown groves and rural shrines, the Wild Mother is shown as a beautiful woman with green skin nearly swallowed by a wild, tangled wreath of hair, leaves, and vines that dwarf her lithe form.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Melora's holy day is Wild's Grandeur, which is celebrated on the vernal equinox, usually the twentieth day of the third month. The people of the Stormkeep set aside this day to sail for no reason other than the pleasure of observing the natural beauty of their surroundings.

items: Protect the untamed wilderness from exploitation and destruction.
Slay abominations and other mockeries of nature.
Embrace and respect the savage nature of the world. Exist in harmony with it.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Melora when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Healing a sick or injured wild animal
Stopping those who hunt for sport or profit
Offering a treasure to the sea
Slaying an aberration, a fiend, or an undead

entries: Your piety score to Melora decreases if you diminish Melora's influence in the world, fail to defend nature, or offend her sensibilities through acts such as these:

items: Killing an animal for any reason other than necessity
Creating buildings, turning a wild field into cropland, or using magic to calm the sea's fury
Destroying the creation of yourself or another
Protecting a city or farm from natural dangers

entries.name: Melora's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Melora trait}

As a devotee of Melora, you have proven yourself a worthy representative of the goddess of the sea. You can cast the {@spell fog cloud} spell with this trait. Fog created in this way smells strongly of the sea. You can cast the spell in this way a number of times equal to your Wisdom (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Melora's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Melora trait}

You can cast the {@spell speak with animals} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.
In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}.

entries.name: Melora's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Melora trait}

When a beast is about to attack you, it must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature must choose a different target, or the attack automatically misses you. On a successful save, the creature is immune to this trait for 24 hours.

entries.name: Caretaker of The Wild
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Melora trait}
You can increase your Dexterity or Wisdom score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Corellon
deity.title: God of Magic and Art
deity.province: Art, Crafts, Magic, Music, Poetry, and Warfare

entries: Guardian of spring, beauty, and the arts, Corellon is the patron of arcane magic and the fey. The Founding inspired them to wander the twisted lands, seeding them with the first arcane magics and raising the most ancient of forests. It was by the Arch Heart's hand that the first elves wandered from the Feywild, and for this reason they are considered the Mother and Father of all elves. Those who seek art in all their work, whether magical or mundane, often worship at the altar of Corellon. They loathe the Spider Queen and her priestesses for leading the drow astray.

Many elf wizards honor Corellon and adorn their spellbooks and towers with the god's symbols. Some of them speculate that Corellon is the personification of raw magic itself, the primal force that underlies the multiverse. Corellon is not magic tamed or shaped—not the Weave, as some name it—but magic in its original form: a well of endless, splendid possibilities.

entries.name: Corellon's Influence
entries: Corellon watches the business of mortals and gods from within the palace of Crescent Grove, a grove depicted as being surrounded by towering white trees and pillars of marble.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Most modern tapestries and tomes depict the Arch Heart as an elven being of impossible grace and beauty, androgynous and alluring, framed by long, wavy, golden hair. They were the inspiration for many early elven art pieces, and elements of their visage or symbol are included in most elven architecture.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Corellon's holy day is called Elvendawn, or Midsummer. It is celebrated on the twentieth day of the sixth month, and commemorates the elves' first emergence from the Feywild. Though the Empire doesn't promote the worship of the Archheart, many elves within Sylingur quietly celebrate in private by opening small doors to the Feywild and having a little more wine than usual.

items: Cultivate beauty in all that you do, whether you’re casting a spell, composing a saga, strumming a lute, or practicing the arts of war.
Seek out lost magic items, forgotten rituals, and ancient works of art. Corellon might have inspired them in the world’s first days.
Thwart the followers of Lolth at every opportunity.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Corellon when you expand the god's influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Following a fleeting passion or taking action on impulse
Creating something wondrous, such as a painting or poem
Discovering a lost piece of magic or art
Destroying the followers of Lolth

entries: Your piety score to Corellon decreases if you diminish Corellon's influence in the world through acts such as these:

items: Preventing a person from following their passions
Selfishly refusing to share art or other things of beauty with the world
Allowing yourself to become stagnant and unchanging
Aiding a follower of Lolth

entries.name: Corellon's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Corellon trait}

As a devotee of Corellon, you have a strong connection to the arcane. You can cast the {@spell detect magic} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
In addition, you know the {@spell mage hand} cantrip. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Corellon's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Corellon trait}

You can cast the {@spell blink} spell with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Corellon's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Corellon trait}
As a Fey warrior of Corellon, you can use your {@spell mage hand} cantrip to protect yourself. While your spectral hand is within 5 feet of you, you gain a +2 bonus to your AC against ranged attacks.

entries.name: Keeper of The Grove
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Corellon trait}
You can increase your Dexterity or Intelligence score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

entries.name: The Blessed of Corellon
entries: Ever changing, mirthful, and beautiful, the primal elves could assume whatever sex they liked. When they bowed to Lolth's influence and chose to fix their physical forms, elves lost the ability to transform in this way. Yet occasionally elves are born who are so androgynous that they are proclaimed to be among the blessed of Corellon-living symbols of the god's love and of the primal elves' original fluid state of being. Many of Corellon's chief priests bear this blessing.

The rarest of these blessed elves can change their sex whenever they finish a long rest-a miracle celebrated by elves of all sorts except drow. (The DM decides whether an elf can manifest this miracle.) Dark elves find this ability to be terrifying and characterize it as a curse, for it could destabilize their entire society. If Corellon's blessing manifests in a drow, that elf usually flees to the surface world to seek shelter among those dedicated to Corellon.

deity.name: Sehanine
deity.title: Goddess of The Moons
deity.province: Autumn, Dreams, Illusion, Love, Moonlight, Night and The Moons

entries: Sehanine is the goddess of moonlight and the autumn season, as well as the patron of illusions and misdirection. Widely worshiped in halfling and elven cultures, she is considered to be the deity of love, protecting the trysts of lovers with shadows of her own making. Those who work in darkness and trickery often ask for her blessing.

entries.name: Sehanine's Influence
entries: Sehanine is said to loom over the skies of Ilúvë as the largest of the two moons, everwatchful that the moons and {@deity Pelor|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers}'s Sun don't collide.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Moon Weaver's depictions are as numerous as the myths and stories of her meddling with the unions of mortals. She is most often painted as a young girl with light-blue skin and white hair, her body and limbs merely wavy silk strands of silver moonlight that caress and create the edges of the shadows around her.
In the Feywild, however, especially there where day is, she is sometimes depicted as a bright red-haired female Ranger, referred to as Ehlonna.

entries.name: Holy Day
entries: Sehanine has no holy day but is celebrated by the elves on the night of the decade's largest full moon. Elven astronomers track the both of the moons' phases and how they grow closer and farther to Ilúvë to predict these days with great accuracy. Many haughty elves use this festival as an excuse to be sly and mischievous, while younger elves use costumes and illusions to prank their peers. Some elves of Sylingur hold a secret festival near The Cloakwood during the full moon, since the Empire doesn't allow worship of the Moon Weaver.

items: Follow your goals and seek your own destiny.
Keep to the shadows, avoiding the blazing light of zealous good and the utter darkness of evil.
Seek new horizons and new experiences, and let nothing tie you down.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Sehanine when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Helping love flourish in the face of adversity
Tempering an extreme course of action with your wisdom
Employing trickery to combat tyranny
Aiding the weak and/or impeding the strong

entries: Your piety score to Sehanine decreases if you diminish Sehanine's influence in the world through acts such as these:

items: Standing in the way of true love
Harming others or putting innocents at risk by falling into extremism
Following unjust laws or upholding an unjust institution

entries.name: Sehanine's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Sehanine trait}

As a devotee of Sehanine, you have proven yourself a worthy potential crusader of the goddess of love and shadows. As a bonus action, you can invoke her protection; twilit shadows cover you, providing you with a +1 bonus to AC for 1 minute. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Sehanine's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Sehanine trait}
You can cast the {@spell moonbeam} spell with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell.
In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}.

entries.name: Sehanine's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Sehanine trait}

By performing an hour-long ritual, you can conjure enough grapes to fill three vials (4 ounces each) of wine. Each vial serves as a {@item potion of healing} or a {@item philter of love} (your choice) for 24 hours, after which time it loses this property. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Lunar Crusader
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Melora trait}
You can increase your Dexterity, Wisdom or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Asmodeus
deity.title: God of Tyranny
deity.province: Envy, Indulgence, Tyranny and Wrath

entries: The devil god of the Hells is the master of tyranny and domination. His words are honeyed and carefully crafted, soothing and corrupting the mortal heart. Asmodeus rules his domain with an iron fist, and the punishments awaiting those that cross him are the basis of nightmares. Evil entities pay him tribute alongside his devils, and many warlocks are drawn to his power.

entries.name: Asmodeus's Influence
entries: Asmodeus is one of the only gods with a physical presence in the realms of Ilúvë. He lords over his fiendish hordes from within his fortress of Nalsheem, nestled in the depths of Nessus, the ninth and deepest of the Nine Hells of Baator.

The reason for this partial banishment, is that he is technically considered an Archdevil, and was thus allowed to keep his devil hordes in check through a more-than-powerful avatar. This Avatar, however, is locked within Baator, and barred from ever entering Ilúvë proper. Not even a {@spell wish} spell could break this curse.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: A twisted image of the celestial blood that once bore him, the Lord of the Nine Hells is revealed in many tomes and murals as a handsome humanoid with deep, red skin and long, black hair. Two curling horns rise from his brow, and his lips bear an eternal, knowing grin.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: Asmodeus's enemies are numerous, even among the Betrayer Gods, many of whom only follow the archdevil for fear of his immense power. His archnemesis is {@deity Avandra|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers}, the Change Bringer, whose mischief and cunning has vexed him throughout the eons. It was she who defeated him in the Dawn War by tricking his fiendish armies into attacking one another. The Devil Lord's greatest triumph during the Dawn War was fooling and betraying the Everlight and slaughtering all her followers in one fell stroke—an act that has united the followers of {@deity Sarenrae|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} and {@deity Avandra|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} in a bond of unbreakable fellowship ever since.

items: Assert dominance and power over others. Show your strength of will in the image of the Asmodeus.
Repay cruelty done unto you with further evil. If others show you kindness, exploit it.
As you ascend to power, do not pity or show mercy to those you climb over to get there. Compassion is for the weak.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Asmodeus when you expand the god's influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Convincing a group of people to accept Asmodeus as a protector
Crushing disorder wherever it may be found
Seizing power from those too weak to keep it for themselves
Honoring the letter of all agreements you make

entries: Your piety score to Asmodeus decreases if you diminish Asmodeus's influence in the world through acts such as these:

items: Showing compassion to those beneath you
Spreading chaos or consorting with demons
Going back on your word or violating an oath

entries.name: Asmodeus's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Asmodeus trait}

As a devotee of Asmodeus, you have proven yourself an agent of the Nine Hells. You can call on Asmodeus's favor to cast the {@spell hellish rebuke} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Asmodeus's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Asmodeus trait}
You can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 60 feet.

entries.name: Asmodeus's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Asmodeus trait}
You have resistance against fire damage and have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}.

entries.name: Demonbane of Baator
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Asmodeus trait}
You can increase your Intelligence or Strength score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Lolth
deity.title: Goddess of Spiders and Lies
deity.province: Deceit, Drow, Lies, Lust, Shadows, Spiders and Women

entries: The evil god of deceit, shadows, and spiders, the Spider Queen weaves a complicated web of schemes and treachery through her worshipers, deceiving allies and enemies alike to gain power. The Spider Queen's worship is entwined with the society of dark elves, even as the drow fall ever deeper into the thrall of the Chained Oblivion's aberrant minions. It is said that the Spider Queen can see through the eyes of all spiders, and that she is truly all-knowing.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Many Lolthite icons and idols show an alluring woman with dark purple skin and silver hair, her abdomen swelling into the terrifying body of a monstrous spider.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: Lolth holds a searing grudge against Kord, the Storm Lord, for with one throw of his mighty thunderspear he impaled her against a cliffside, leaving her drow armies leaderless during the Dawn War. Lolth and Gruumsh also share a burning hatred for Corellon, whom she claims drove her children below the earth, and Lolth often manipulates Gruumsh's followers into attacking her enemies so that the drow may remain safe.

items: Misdirection, slander, and shadowed steps have more function than direct conflict.
It is better to be loved than feared, but you may certainly try to be both.
Death to the elves who live under the sun, and death to all their allies!

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Lolth when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Subjugating lesser creatures or sacrificing them to Lolth
Pulling off a daring robbery or perpetuating a bold lie
Obstructing champions of other gods
Desecrating temples to Corellon or Sehanine

entries: Your piety score to Lolth decreases if you diminish her influence in the world, contradict her ideals, or make her look ridiculous or ineffectual through acts such as these:

items: Forthrightly assisting lawgivers in their duties
Bringing order in times of chaos, except through domination and subjugation
Knowingly aiding a practicing follower of Corellon or Sehanine.

entries.name: Lolth's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Lolth trait}

As a devotee of Lolth, you have proven yourself accomplished at deception. You can call on Lolth's blessing and cast {@spell disguise self} with this trait. While the spell is active, While the spell is active, your shadow still resembles your original form as if seen in moonlight. You can cast the spell in this way a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Lolth's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Lolth trait}
Your words are inspired by the Spider Queen with her web of Lies. You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Deception}) checks.

entries.name: Lolth's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Lolth trait}
When you are hidden from a creature and miss it with an attack, making the attack doesn't reveal your position.

entries.name: Champion of the Demonweb Pits
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Lolth trait}
You can increase your Dexterity or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Tharizdun
deity.title: God of Madness
deity.province: Annihalation, Entropy, Eternal Darkness, Decay, Insanity and Ruinatoin

entries: It is darkness unending, less like a god and more like another world. Life and death do not exist within Tharizdun, only utter destruction and madness. Even the other Betrayer Gods treat this mad god with caution. In its endless imprisonment, Tharizdun dreams the infinite depths of the Abyss into reality, along with all its demonic legions. The Prime Deities had thought it locked away during the Creation Era until it nearly returned to ruin the world during the conflicts of the Dawn War.

Now, its chaotic mind has fallen into more frightful dreams, imagining nightmarish aberrations into existence deep beneath Ilúvë. The Chained Oblivion's demented cultists work without word from their twisted patron, awaiting the Epoch of Ends, when its freedom will be attained and all beings shall be consumed in deathlessness unending.

entries.name: Tharizdun's Influence
entries: Tharizdun, being something far more powerful than the gods, is believed to be chained in the deepest pits of the Abyss, bound by divine shackles that slowly weaken, leaking its madness into the planes.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Few visual attempts to depict Tharizdun exist, but the texts speak of a creature of rolling, hungry ink, gnashing teeth and darkness, a spreading cloud of lightless destruction born from a thousand ravenous mouths. Current references show the nightmare constrained by chains of gold and black, barely keeping the dark at bay.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: The few remaining followers of Ioun are dedicated to ensuring that Tharizdun is never again unchained. Ioun led the charge against the all-consuming destroyer god's reemergence, and her bravery allowed the other Prime Deities to shackle their enemy, though the victory nearly cost her immortal life. Some say Ioun can only be fully restored if the Chained Oblivion is destroyed for good.

items: Offer and siphon power to Tharizdun until his liberation comes.
Uncover, restore, and exalt forgotten shrines and relics in his honor.
Ruin and raze the realms to prepare for the Epoch of Ends.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Tharizdun when you expand the god's influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Razing a settlement to the ground
Restoring shrines and relics of Tharizdun from ancient times
Teaching people about Tharizdun, his nature, and his inevitable return

entries: Your piety score to Tharizdun decreases if you diminish his influence in the world through acts such as these:

items: Imposing order on a chaotic situation
Building or creating structures or systems
Assisting a creature in undermining or subverting the inevitable march of entropy

entries.name: Tharizdun's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Tharizdun trait}

As a devotee of Tharizdun, you sow chaos wherever you go. You can cast the {@spell chaos bolt} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Tharizdun's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Tharizdun trait}

You are adept and summoning minions of chaos. You can cast the {@spell summon lesser demon} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Tharizdun's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Tharizdun trait}
As a disciple of the Chained God, you find bondage blasphemous in all its forms. You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition paralyzed} and {@condition restrained}.

entries.name: Abyssal Insanitor
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Tharizdun trait}
You can increase your Constitution or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Tiamat
deity.title: Goddess of Greed
deity.province: Chromatic Dragons, Greed, Hatred and Revenge
deity.symbol: Five-pointed star with curved points, each in the color of a Chromatic Dragon

entries: The evil queen of dragons is a fearsome god of greed, envy, and hoarded wealth. While chromatic dragons are her foremost worshipers, Tiamat accepts the worship of any who crave wealth. All chromatic dragons have a fearful reverence for their tyrannical queen, but many dragons of near-deific power and ambition chafe under her rule.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Most representations of Tiamat exist as warnings within sanctuaries of the Platinum Dragon. She is shown as a drake of frightful size, with massive leathery wings spreading clouds of poisonous mist, while she shouts from five vicious dragon heads, each one a chromatic color of her evil children.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: The Scaled Tyrant's hatred for {@deity Pelor|The Prime Deities|Bahamut} is as old as the Founding, and her cults are ever hunted by his justice. For centuries, the zealous paladins of Bahamut have limited her worship to the chromatic dragons, but a rise in cult activity in the underbelly of Dwendalian society has priests of the Platinum Dragon on edge.

items: Amass wealth, but spend little. The gold—and the power that comes with it—is sufficient reward in itself.
Do not forgive nor forget an indignity to yourself. Let no affront go unpunished.
Take what you covet. Those without the strength to defend their dominion are not worthy to have one.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Tiamat when you expand her influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Aiding the plots of a chromatic dragon or giving one offerings of treasure
Taking vengeance on someone who as wronged you
Taking material wealth from the less deserving
Thwarting the schemes of Bahamut

entries: Your piety score to Tiamat decreases if you diminish Tiamat's influence in the world or weaken her dominion through acts such as these:

items: Slaying or hindering a chromatic dragon
Allowing a slight against you to go unpunished
Giving up material wealth without personal benefit commensurate with the spent coin, especially for charitable causes

entries.name: Tiamat's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Tiamat trait}

As a devotee of Tiamat, you wield the might of corrupted dragons. You can call on Tiamat's favor to cast the {@spell cause fear} spell with this trait, requiring no material components, a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Tiamat's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Tiamat trait}

You can cast the {@spell dragon's breath} spell at third level with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Tiamat's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Tiamat trait}

Tiamat's favor grants you resistance to your choice of acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage. Whenever you finish a short rest, you can change the type of damage you are resistant to to a different type from the same list. Additionally, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Dragonnet of Azharul
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Tiamat trait}
You can increase your Strength or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Torog
deity.title: God of The Underdark
deity.province: The Underdark, Enslavement, Imprisonment and Torture
deity.symbol: Letter "T" attached to a circular shackle

entries: The dark god of the endless tunnels and caverns beneath Ilúvë, Torog is the patron of torturers, slavers, and jailers across the realms. His violent tears carved the pathways under the world, and his realm of imprisonment is a network of deadly caves and manacles from which few return. Creatures that wander the desolation of Carceri often construct prisons in his image. Those who rob others of their freedom offer prayers to him in cellars and other subterranean domains, and many creatures who live in the darkness below worship him and seek his guidance.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: The Crawling King is rendered as a swollen, malformed worm that slithers through the dark below, with a screaming, hairless human head at the helm and three arms carving through the lightless rock.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: {@deity Pelor|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} and {@deity Sarenrae|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} defeated Torog during the Dawn War by luring their nemesis above ground. Pelor pierced Torog's tenebrous body with ten thousand lances of sunlight, and the Everlight imprisoned him beyond the boundaries of Ilúvë. The tears of pain and anger the Crawling King shed burned through Ilúvë, and his faithful fled into these tunnels to escape their enemies' holy light.

items: Seek and exalt places where no light touches.
Revel in the pain you inflict on others, and relish the pain you suffer yourself as an offering to Torog.
Imprison those who cannot resist you, and drag all life into the darkness.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Torog when you expand his influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Imprisoning a powerful foe
Learning useful information through torture
Building or maintaining an underground temple to the King Who Crawls

entries: Your piety score to Torog decreases if you diminish Torog's influence in the world, contradict his ideals, or make him look ridiculous or ineffectual through acts such as these:

items: Allowing a prisoner to go free
Soothing the pain of a creature in agony
Failing to pay homage to the King Who Crawls when traveling underground

entries.name: Torog's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Torog trait}

As a devotee of Torog, you can call upon the power of his greatest creation: the prison plane Carceri. You can cast the {@spell armor of Agathys} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Torog's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Torog trait}

You can cast the {@spell Maximilian's earthen grasp|XGE} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.
In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}.

entries.name: Torog's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Torog trait}
