You gain a burrowing speed equal to your walking speed. You can use your burrowing speed to move through sand, loose earth, mud, or ice, not solid rock.

entries.name: Chainmaster of The Underdark
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Torog trait}
You can increase your Strength or Constitution score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Vecna
deity.title: God of Secrets
deity.province: Evil, Coveting, Dark Magic, Knowledge, Secrets and Undeath

entries: Vecna is the evil god of undead, necromancy, and secrets. He rules that which is not meant to be known and that which people wish to keep secret. Vecna is considered the most powerful and the most evil lich in history. He rose to godhood, becoming the god of secrets.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Those who claim to have looked on Vecna's form speak of a tall, skeletal lich swathed in tattered robes and enchanted jewels, missing both his left hand and left eye.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: While Vecna loathes all other gods and wishes to destroy them and become the sole divine power in the planes, he has a particular hatred for {@deity Ioun|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers}. Ioun seeks to share with the world the same secrets Vecna guards for himself, and his followers have worked diligently to undermine and destroy the Library of the Chroniclers and any others who follow her path. The Raven Queen also despises Vecna, and sees his presence as a mighty affront to her purpose.

items: Learn all you can, and keep hidden that which you know. Reveal what pieces you must, but never the whole.
Express and cultivate the evil within yourself, and in doing so, recognize it in others to exploit them for your own benefit.
Seed the ruin of all who worship other deities, until only those who kneel before Vecna remain.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Vecna when you expand his influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Keeping a secret despite personal cost, harm to society, or its potential to benefit others
Taking vengeance on one who has wronged you
Uncovering and abusing forbidden lore and black magic
Raising the dead to do your bidding

entries: Your piety score to Vecna decreases if you diminish Vecna's influence in the world through acts such as these:

items: Revealing a secret that should remain unknown
Furthering the aims of another god
Destroying dark secrets or forbidden knowledge

entries.name: Vecna's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Vecna trait}

As a devotee of Vecna, you have proven yourself a disciple of black magic. You can call on Vecna's favor to cast the {@spell inflict wounds} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Vecna's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Vecna trait}

You can cast the {@spell animate dead} spell with this trait. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Vecna's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Vecna trait}
You resist necrotic damage, and you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Whisperer of the Maimed Lord
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Vecna trait}
You can increase your Constitution or Intellligence score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

deity.name: Zehir
deity.title: God of Darkness and Poison
deity.province: Assassins, Darkness, Thievery, Poison and Snakes
deity.symbol: Snake in the shape of a dagger

entries: A wanderer in the shadows and the creator of snakes and serpentkin, Zehir is the evil god of poisons, assassins, and darkness. The ancient serpentkin worship him over all other deities, dragging screaming offerings to their temples in his honor. Most of the Midnight Serpent's worshipers were annihilated during the Dawn War, however recently Zehir has started to gain more prominence after re-emerging as a god worshipped by the Ashen Drow of Nordabád.

entries.name: Depiction
entries: Many forgotten temples were once built to the Cloaked Serpent, and within these chambers his image was embedded within much of the architecture. He is shown as a human body with six arms and a gargantuan serpentine head, fanged and frilled in aggression. Strands of thick, dark hair that sprout from his scaled body form layers of swirling shadow, obscuring his form.

entries.name: Enemies
entries: Zehir loathes {@deity Erathis|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} and {@deity Melora|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers}, for he despises life, order, and love above all things. His surviving worshipers use poison and fire to undermine civilization and consume nature, hoping to infuriate both gods and cast Ilúvë into chaos.

items: Hide under the cloak of night, that your deeds might be kept in secret.
Kill in Zehir's name and offer each murder as a sacrifice.
Delight in poison, and surround yourself with snakes.

entries.name: Earning and Losing Piety
entries: You increase your piety score to Zehir when you expand his influence in the world in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Assassinating a target under cover of night
Laying low a powerful foe by using poison
Building or restoring a temple to Zehir, or a site that glorifies serpentine creatures
Desecrating temples of {@deity Pelor|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers}

entries: Your piety score to Zehir decreases if you diminish Zehir's influence in the world, contradict his ideals, or make him look ridiculous or ineffectual through acts such as these:

items: Destroying a rare poison, or curing a person afflicted by poison
Conducting an honorable duel or other honest business in broad daylight
Slaying a medusa, yuan-ti, or other serpent creature

entries.name: Zehir's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Zehir trait}

As a devotee of Zehir, you have power over affliction. You can cast the {@spell ray of sickness} spell with this trait a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Zehir's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Zehir trait}
Zehir's blessing shields you from most maladies. You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}, and you are immune to disease.

entries.name: Zehir's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Zehir trait}
Zehir blesses you so that your very touch is poisonous. As an action, you can touch a creature and choose one of the following:

items: The target must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

The target must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

The target must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, or for 1 minute, the target deals only half damage with weapon attacks. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

entries: You can use this action a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Warrior of Samaragd
entries: {@i Piety 50+ Zehir trait}
You can increase your Dexterity or Intelligence score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

entries: You increase your piety score to Kossuth when you expand his influence in the world or in the plane of Fire in a concrete way through acts such as these:

items: Burning buildings, creatures and other entities as a means of renewal
Creating fires and shrines in Kossuth's honor
Defeating followers of Bwimb, Rorn and, most importantly, Istishia

entries: Your piety score to Kossuth decreases if you diminish his influence in the world through acts such as these:

items: Dousing flames or using water-based magic
Willingly helping a follower of Istishia
Failing to comply to his demands

entries.name: Kossuth's Devotee
entries: {@i Piety 3+ Kossuth trait}

As a cultist of Kossuth, you become "bound in flame", and as such gain the ability to guide Kossuth's purifying flame to a destination you desire. You can cast the {@spell guiding bolt} spell, which deals fire damage instead of radiant, without needing to provide material components with this trait a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Kossuth's Votary
entries: {@i Piety 10+ Kossuth trait}

You can cast the {@spell fireball} spell with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

entries.name: Kossuth's Disciple
entries: {@i Piety 25+ Kossuth trait}
Your connection to Kossuth deepens further, granting you resistance to fire damage. In addition, if you are on fire, you can put it out as a bonus action.

entries.name: Firemonger

You can increase your Constitution or Charisma score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

feat.name: Mystic Conflux
entries: Through your repeated exposure of the natural flow of arcane magic throughout Ilúvë, you've adapted to attune with additional enchantments, though the process can by physically taxing. You gain the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) checks when investigating the nature of a magical object or device.
You can now be attuned to a maximum of four magical items, rather than the normal limit of three. Other attunement limitations still apply.

feat.name: Nocturnal
entries: Due to extensive exposure to the dark, and possible supernatural abilities, you have an unmatched ability to fight adversaries in the dark. You gain the following benefits:

items: You gain Darkvision with a radius of 60 feet. If you already have darkvision, then the radius of your darkvision increases by 30 feet, to a maximum of 120 feet.
You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks while in dim light or nonmagical darkness.
You can try to hide when you are lightly obscured from the creature from which you are hiding.
When you are hidden from a creature and miss it with a ranged weapon attack, making the attack doesn't reveal your position.
Dim light doesn't impose disadvantage on your Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks relying on sight.

entries: {@i NOTE: This feat replaces the Skulker feat.}

feat.name: Mending Affinity
entries: Your body has begun to adapt extremely well to healing itself through extraordinary means, gifting you the following benefits:

items: When a creature uses a {@item healer's kit|ArcaneWhispers} to stabilize you when you are dying, you also regain hit points equal to your proficiency modifier.
Whenever you regain hit points as a result of a spell, potion, or class ability, you regain additional hit points equal to your proficiency modifier.

feat.name: Dual-focused
entries: Countless hours have been spent training your mind to maintain focus on concurrent incantations, taxing as the process may be.

items: If you attempt to cast a spell that requires concentration while already concentrating on an existing spell, you can maintain concentration on both spells simultaneously.
If you take damage during this time, you must make a concentration check for each spell individually.

At the end of each turn where you have two spells you are concentrating on, you must make a Constitution saving throw (DC equals 8 + both spells' levels combined). On a success, you maintain concentration on both spells. On a failure, you lose concentration on both spells.

feat.name: Thrown Arms Master
entries: You've honed your ability to lob weaponry into the fray, including weapons not meant for ranged combat. You gain the following benefits:

items: Simple and martial melee weapons without the thrown property can be treated as if they have the thrown property. One-handed weapons have a range of 20/60, while two-handed weapons have a range of 15/30.
Weapons that naturally have the thrown property increase their range by +20/+40.
When you miss with a thrown weapon attack using a {@i light} weapon, the weapon immediately boomerangs back into your grasp.

item.name: Band of Loyalty
entries: If you are reduced to zero hit points while attuned to a band of loyalty, you instantly die. These rings are favored by spies who can't afford to fall into enemy hands.

item.name: Aegis of Radiance
entries: This golden shield emits a faint, holy glow when wielded and recognizes your devotion to a higher power. When you attune to this shield, the emblem adorning its face changes to one that represents your chosen deity, allowing you to use the shield as a holy symbol. You gain a +1 bonus to your AC while wielding this shield in addition to the shield's normal bonus to AC.

While wielding the shield, you can speak its command word as a bonus action to cause it to shatter into countless fragments of pure light. The pieces of light protect you as if you were wielding the shield, leaving your hands free. The light surrounds you for 1 minute, until you dismiss the effect as a bonus action, or until you fall unconscious or die, at which point the shield rematerializes on the ground at your feet or into your hand if you have one free. If your holy symbol is emblazoned or attached to the shield, it floats prominently amidst the shards of light and continues to function as a spellcasting focus. Undead creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls made against you while you're surrounded by the light in this way. The surrounding shards of light cast bright light in a 20 foot radius and dim light for another 20 feet. Once this property has been used, it can't be used again until the following dawn.

item.name: Dawnfang, The Star-Breaker
item.reqAttune: by a cleric, paladin or warlock
entries: This enchanted weapon has taken multiple forms across the ages, the most prominent of which a longsword. This blade was created by {@deity Pelor|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers} and breathed into existence by his most mighty mount, the ancient Phoenix {@i Aurosion}.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls you make with this magic weapon. This weapon deals an additional 1d8 radiant damage to undead.

When you kill an undead with this magic weapon, roll {@dice 1d10}. If you roll a 1 or 2, the undead's body bursts into blue flame that deals 2d8 fire damage to all undead within 10 feet of it. The flame does no damage and produces no noticeable heat to other types of creatures. If you are proficient with either Longswords, Greatswords, Rapiers and Shortswords, you are proficient with Dawnfang.

item.name: Staff of the Pyre
entries: This gnarled wooden staff was once used by an evil hag warlock, known as the Glenfire Hag.
While holding the {@i staff of the pyre}, you gain a +1 bonus to damage rolls when casting a spell or making an attack that deals fire damage.

item.name: Cage of Concealment
entries: This small rusted iron cage can hold one tiny or smaller creature inside it with ease.

The outside of this cage looks like an empty cage, but is actually lined with a thin illusonary curtain from the inside, making it appear as if anything placed inside the cage is {@condition invisible}. As an action, you can stow one creature or object no larger than 2 cubic feet into the cage.

item.name: Gilded Bell of Arcanix
entries: This bell was used as a last-ditch effort to push back the forces of Thalor Ancalen during the Crown Wars. It was enchanted by the great Sage and Seer known as Azura Denduledáin, and was lost during the Crown Wars. It now bears little resemblance to the ancient enchantment used, as the residual magic of Arcanix has twisted it's very nature.
In addition, the robe has {@dice 4d4} other patches. The DM chooses the patches or determines them randomly.

Iron door (up to 10 feet wide and 10 feet high, barred on one side of your choice), which you can place in an opening you can reach; it conforms to fit the opening, attaching and hinging itself

item.name: Runestone, Brimstone
entries: This small runestone seems suffused with malicious energy.

As an action, you can throw this stone, hitting one enemy of your choice within 60 feet of you. The stone deals fire damage equal to {@damage 2d12} + your Dexterity or Intelligence modifier (your choice), and is destroyed upon impact.

item.name: Blade of Gluttony
entries: This gorgeous Claymore is engraved with elven sigils along its blade, which glow a deep crimson. A crystal of pure brimstone adorns the center of the pommel, glowing with a malicious orange energy.
The magical effects of this weapon are not revealed by an {@spell identify} spell and any attempt to uncover its nature without attuning to it fails.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, which deals an additional {@dice 2d6} fire damage on a hit.

The sword has 20 charges for the following properties. The sword regains {@dice 2d8 + 4} expended charges daily at dawn. . If you expend the last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the sword retains its +3 bonus to attack and damage roll but loses all other properties. On a 20, the sword regains {@dice 1d8 + 2} charges.

entries.name: Brimstone Hunger
entries: When you hit with a creature using this weapon, you can expend 1 charge to deal an extra {@dice 1d6} necrotic damage to the target.

entries.name: Spells
entries: While holding this magic weapon, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast one of the following spells from it (save DC 18): {@spell blindness/deafness} (2 charges), {@spell blink} (3 charges), {@spell dimension door} (4 charges), {@spell fireball} (5th-level version, 5 charges), {@spell fire storm} (6 charges),  {@spell heat metal} (2 charges), {@spell hellish rebuke} (5th-level version, 5 charges), {@spell hunger of hadar} (3 charges), {@spell investiture of flame|XGE} (6 charges) or {@spell wall of fire} (4 charges).
In addition, you have immunity to fire damage while attuned to this magic weapon.

item.name: Brigandine Armor
entries: A brigandine is a form of body armour. It is a garment, generally heavy cloth, canvas or leather, lined with small oblong steel plates riveted to the fabric.

item.name: Lumenstone
entries: Lumenstone, otherwise known as Faronaar or rarely Lightstone, is a mineral which forms in clusters where magic runs rampant. It is used in enchanting, wherein it is processed to become a {@item Focal Stone|ArcaneWhispers}. It is otherwise used as a material in armor, as its magic-infused properties grant a slight resistance to magic.
Thus, any armor created with Lumenstone reduces damage taken by direct magic (such as {@spell fireball} and {@spell magic missile}) by 1.

item.name: Focal Stone
entries: The first step in creating a magical item is the initial plan for its function. During this step, a mage, while researching the spells, will also need to gather {@i Focal Stones}. These stones are gemstones, most of which are made from {@item Lumenstone|ArcaneWhispers}.

A Focal Stone can store up to 9 levels worth of spell slots, which the wielder can imbue into the Focal Stone by holding the stone in one hand and casting a spell. The spell then has no effect, other than to be stored in the Focal Stone. Once the Focal Stone has at least one level worth of spell slots, it can be used as a material component in the {@spell Transfer Enchantment} spell. While a Focal Stone can practically be used indefinitely, the more it is used, the more unstable the casting.
In addition, a Focal Stone can also be used as a spellcasting focus.

variantrule.name: Races of The World of Light
entries: The races of Ilúvë vary widely from continent to continent. Being a harsh world, many races have adapted to those hard environments, some even going as far as to completely embody that particular harsness in the form of slavery and warmongering. Whatever the case, below is given a list of all of the allowed playable races, sorted first by continent and secondly by rarity.

entries.name: Greywood, The Mainland
entries: Greywood is a continent of magic and malice. It's the starting continent for Of Might And Magic and Whispers of The Arcane, and it's the most varied in its races.

items: {@race Dwarf (Hill)|PHB|Hill Dwarves}, {@race Dwarf (Mountain)|PHB|Mountain Dwarves} and the ever-resented {@race Dwarf (Duergar)|MTF|Grey Dwarves} (otherwise known as Duergar).
Most Dwarves on Greywood dwell deep in the Ironpeak mountain range. There are four known Dwarven Clans on Greywood, which are as follows:

Clan Coppercoin - Mostly Hill Dwarves, especially adept at selling and procuring goods; expert merchants, most travel the globe and Greywood alike in search of {@deity Moradin|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers|Moradin's} blessing.

Clan Greyhand - Strictly Mountain Dwarves. The least-known Dwarvish Clan, said to have unearthed {@deity Lunitari|Ilúvë|ArcaneWhispers|Lunitari's} secret. This clan is mostly shrouded in secrecy, as they are also said to keep the other Clans in check, without direct intervention.

Clan Cindersmith - A Clan of mostly Duegar and a small amount of Mountain Dwarves. This Clan is known to create many weapons for Clan Coppercoin to sell, and is also known as the Clan responsible for most "Good"-aligned Duegar. This Clan is also the only known clan to take in Gnomish Alchemists, Crafters and Artificers.

Clan Steelborn - A Clan of every type of Dwarf, most notably Mountain Dwarves. This Clan is most widespread near and in the Ironpeak Mountains, and one city can even be seen gleaming betwixt two mountains; the City of Dor-Durgarn.
{@race Elf (High)|PHB|High Elves}, {@race Elf (Wood)|PHB|Wood Elves} and {@race Drow|PHB|Dark Elves} (Otherwise known as Drow).

The Elves of Greywood are a tall, proud and more often than not, haughty race. The Elves were the first people of this land. They were the fey descendants who first named their homeland Syndar, centuries before humans gave it the name Greywood. The common origin of most elves lies within the wooded lands of what is now known as Sylingur, and many elves—Wood Elves and High Elves alike—still call the great forests their home.
{@race Goblin (Ash)|ArcaneWhispers|Ash Goblins}, {@race Goblin (Deep)|ArcaneWhispers|Deep Goblins} and {@race Goblin (Forest)|ArcaneWhispers|Forest Goblins}.

Whether they're wreaking havoc within the Shrouded Crags of Rana Mor, scurrying along the Wastes of Nordabád, or hidden in the Forest of Amoor-dânn and Aeldwen, Goblins are widespread and come in many different shapes and sizes. Similar to the {@race Dwarf|PHB|Dwarves}, many Goblins ally themselves with—or are born into—a clan.

{@race Goblin (Ash)|ArcaneWhispers|Ash Goblins}. Ash Goblins scurry about on the Ashen Plains, defiling Orcish shrines betwixt the peaks of the Obsidian Ridge, and hauling along slaves and produce along the treacherous crags and desolate plains of the Wastes of Nordabád.

{@race Goblin (Deep)|ArcaneWhispers|Deep Goblins}. Deep Goblins chose to venture into the deepest pits of the Underdark, choosing to venerate Torog, purely out of fear. The many many years below ground has turned most of them blind, and this is directly seen in their armor; eyeless armor created from the Chitin of the oversized Shellbugs they ride into battle.

{@race Goblin (Forest)|ArcaneWhispers|Forest Goblins}. Forest Goblins are among the most varied, and even within the clans most Forest Goblins aren't without many differences. Forest Goblins are also seen as the most trustworthy, though this is very dependant on the clan-alliance of the goblin and even the forest one would find it in.

There are possibly thousands of goblin clans, situated along the Ironpeak Mountains, the Obsian Ridge, the Forest of Amoor-dânn and even the Fens and Bogs of the Ghostmere. The most prominent of which include the following:

{@b The Drar-Okaan}. Having been rendered blind to the caverns of the Underdark, the {@race Goblin (Deep)|ArcaneWhispers|Deep Goblins} of the Drar-Okaan tribe attempt to live by their wits—though seldom with much success. When a Drar-Okaan Goblin has the bright idea of trying to tame Rust Monster Larvae, at least a few others will be willing to follow that goblin into a nest—usually to predictably horrible results. But though the Drar-Okaan seem to have a never-ending supply of bad ideas, and a horrible ratio of bad ideas to good, the Drar-Okaan likewise seem to have a never-ending supply of Drar-Okaan. As such, by trial and error (and more error), these Goblins have stumbled across a great deal of knowledge useful for surviving the deep places of Ilúvë, and for dealing with the creatures that live there.

{@b The Ol'Rith'Narr Kinship}. Possibly the largest uneasy alliance between hordes of Goblins, the Ol'Rith'Narr Kinship is a large tribe consisting of both Warmongering, Bloodthirsty {@race Goblin (Ash)|ArcaneWhispers|Ash Goblins}, {@race Orc|PHB|Orcs} and a strange mix of Chromatic (usually black-scaled) {@race Dragonborn|ArcaneWhispers|Dragonborn} occupying most of the Wastes of Nordabád. Throughout the ranks of the Ol'Rith'Narr, action and strength are valued above diplomacy, and its leaders earn respect by the blade, wasting no time with politics. The brutality of the Ol'Rith'Narr's champions is focused, giving a voice to those who fight for survival. It is also widely known that the Ol'Rith'Narr are a major chess piece in the Arcaborian Empire's slipping grip of their dominion over the Wastes, going so far as that the Empire now no longer considers Nordabád to be under their rule.

{@b The Redclaw Clan}. The most lighthearted of the three prominent clans, the Redclaw Clan is home to many {@race Goblin (Forest)|ArcaneWhispers|Forest Goblins}, and have a special, magical facepaint that shows other members of the Redclaw Clan their allegiance. Members of the Redclaw clan guard places of Civilization against the lesser evils, and see themselves as neutral (though chaotic at times) forces to stop the lesser evils from encroaching into the safe walls of cities like The Old City and Myth Ancalen. In addition, the Redclaw Clan is most well-known for Smunsen's Soup Emporium; a place hidden—albeit not very well—within the Forests that surround the Old City.
{@race Halfling (Lightfoot)|PHB|Lightfoot Halflings} and {@race Halfling (Stout)|PHB|Stout Halflings}.
The Children of Avandra.

{@race Half-Elf|PHB|Half-Elves}. After the fledgling races found themselves on the world of Ilúvë, soon they began intermingling, with the ever-so-adventrous elves to try many different pairings, creating the Half-Elves. Most Half-Elves on Greywood are the direct result of Human and High-Elven or Wood-Elven pairings, Though pairings of elves with other races also exist, albeit they are rare.

entries: The Vilt, consisting of the two Poles of Ilúvë, Nordurvilt and Sudrvilt, lie to the far north and south of Greywood, and is home to giants, ettins, yeti's and other coldborn races.

{@race Human|PHB|Humans}. Humans of the Vilt are far and between, and are just as ruthless as their Orc and Half-Orc brethren. Originally tribes hailing from Greywood, most humans that migrated to The Vilt sought to worship the gods of pride and conquest, believing in the more barbaric way of life. When playing a human from the Vilt, players can choose between both the {@race Human|PHB} and {@race Human (Variant)|PHB|Variant Human} subraces as well as the {@race Human (Mark of Handling)|ERLW} and {@race Human (Keldon)|PSD} subraces.

entries.name: Age
entries: Young dragonborn grow quickly. They walk hours after hatching, attain the size and development of a 10-year-old human child by the age of 3, and reach adulthood by 15. They live to be around 80.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Dragonborn tend to extremes, making a conscious choice for one side or the other in the cosmic war between good and evil (represented by Bahamut and Tiamat, respectively). Most dragonborn are good, but those who side with Tiamat can be terrible villains.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: Dragonborn are taller and heavier than humans, standing well over 6 feet tall and averaging almost 250 pounds. If you are Medium, you count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift. Your size is Medium or Large.

entries.name: Gem Ancestry
entries: You have a gem dragon ancestor, granting you a special magical affinity. Choose one kind of dragon from the Gem Ancestry table. This determines the damage type for your other traits, as shown in the table.

entries.name: Breath Weapon
entries: When you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with an exhalation of magical energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC = 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus). On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 1d10} damage of the type associated with your Gem Ancestry. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage. This damage increases by {@dice 1d10} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d10}), 11th level ({@dice 3d10}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d10}).
You can use your Breath Weapon a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Draconic Resistance
entries: You have resistance to the damage type associated with your Gem Ancestry.

entries.name: Psionic Mind
entries: You can send telepathic messages to any creature you can see within 30 feet of you. You don't need to share a language with the creature for it to understand these messages, but it must be able to understand at least one language to comprehend them.

entries.name: Gem Flight
entries: Starting at 5th level, you can use a bonus action to manifest spectral wings on your body. These wings last for 1 minute. For the duration, you gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed and can hover. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for your character.

entries.name: Draconic Ancestry
entries: You have draconic ancestry. Choose one type of dragon from the Draconic Ancestry table. Your breath weapon and damage resistance are determined by the dragon type, as shown in the table.

entries.name: Breath Weapon
entries: You can use a bonus action to exhale destructive energy. Your draconic ancestry determines the size, shape, and damage type of the exhalation.

When you use your breath weapon, each creature in the area of the exhalation must make a saving throw, the type of which is determined by your draconic ancestry. The DC for this saving throw equals 8 + your Charisma modifier + your proficiency bonus. A creature takes {@dice 1d12} damage on a failed save, and half as much damage on a successful one. The damage increases to {@dice 2d12} at 5th level, {@dice 3d12} at 11th level, and {@dice 4d12} at 17th level.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of once). You regain any expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Draconic Strength
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: If you are Medium, you count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Damage Resistance
entries: You have resistance to the damage type associated with your draconic ancestry.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Draconic. Draconic is thought to be one of the oldest languages and is often used in the study of magic. The language sounds harsh to most other creatures and includes numerous hard consonants and sibilants.

entries.name: Age
entries: Goblins reach adulthood at age 8 and live up to 60 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Ash goblins are typically lawful evil, as ride in packs on their fearsome worgs, prefering to hunt together. A few goblins might tend toward good or neutrality, but only rarely.

entries.name: Size
entries: Ash goblins are the largest and strongest of the goblin subraces; they are anywhere between 4 and just under 5 feet tall and weigh between 80 and 120 pounds. If you embody the bulkier sides of the Ash Goblins, your size is Medium, and if you embody the smaller grunts of the Ash Goblins, your size is Small.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Nimble Escape
entries: You can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide action} as a bonus action on each of your turns.

entries.name: Fury of the Small
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or a spell and the creature's size is larger than yours, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Worg Rider
entries: Ash goblins have an amicable relationship with worgs, whom they ride into battle. You have proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Goblin.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Deep goblins are typically neutral evil, as they care only for their own needs. A few goblins might tend toward good or neutrality, but only rarely.

entries.name: Size
entries: Deep goblins are between 3 and 4 feet tall and weigh between 40 and 80 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Blindsight
entries: Deep goblins thrive in the many caves and caverns beneath the world, though years and years in the darkness has rendered them blind. Thus, you have Blindsense out to a range of 30 feet. You are blind beyond this radius.

entries.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: You have disadvantage on attack rolls and on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight when you, the target of your attack, or whatever you are trying to perceive is in direct sunlight.

entries.name: Fury of the Small
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or a spell and the creature's size is larger than yours, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Naturally Stealthy
entries: You can attempt to hide even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.

entries.name: Stoneskin
entries: You can move across difficult terrain made of earth or stone without expending extra movement.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Goblin.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Forest goblins are typically neutral or neutral good, though some mischievous forest goblins are chaotic neutral.

entries.name: Size
entries: Forest goblins are smaller than most Ash Goblins, though some tribes prefer lanky and tall offspring. Your size is Small or Medium.
